{"contents":"# Conversation Backup Guide

## Quick Start

Yes, you can store all your conversations! Here's how:

### Option 1: Quick Save (Easiest)
1. After an important conversation, run: `quick-save.bat`
2. Paste your conversation notes
3. Press Ctrl+Z and Enter
4. Done! File saved in `conversation-logs/` folder

### Option 2: Full Backup with Git (Recommended)
1. **First time setup:**
   - Run `setup-git-backup.bat`
   - Follow the prompts to connect to GitHub/GitLab
   
2. **After conversations:**
   - Run `save-conversation.bat`
   - Enter a description
   - Paste your notes
   - It will automatically commit to git and push online

## What Gets Saved?

- All conversation logs go to `conversation-logs/` folder
- Files are named with date/time: `YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-SS-description.md`
- Everything is stored in markdown format (easy to read and search)

## Online Backup Options

### GitHub (Free, Recommended)
1. Create account at https://github.com
2. Create new repository (make it private if you want)
3. Run `setup-git-backup.bat` and paste your repo URL
4. All conversations will be backed up online automatically

### GitLab (Free Alternative)
- Similar to GitHub
- Good for private repositories
- Run `setup-git-backup.bat` and choose option 2

### OneDrive/Google Drive (Already Available)
- Just copy the `conversation-logs` folder to your cloud drive
- Simple file sync, no git needed

## Manual Git Commands

If you prefer manual control:

```powershell
# Add conversation logs
git add conversation-logs/

# Commit
git commit -m "Save conversation about [topic]"

# Push to online backup
git push
```

## Privacy & Security

- **Public repositories:** Anyone can see your conversations
- **Private repositories:** Only you can see (recommended for sensitive data)
- Review conversations before committing if they contain sensitive info

## File Structure

```
Desktop/
â”œâ”€â”€ conversation-logs/          # All your conversation logs
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ README.md              # Instructions
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 2025-01-20-14-30-00-erpnext-setup.md
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ 2025-01-20-15-45-00-bug-fix.md
â”œâ”€â”€ save-conversation.bat      # Main save script
â”œâ”€â”€ setup-git-backup.bat       # One-time setup
â””â”€â”€ quick-save.bat            # Quick save script
```

## Tips

1. **Save regularly:** Don't wait too long between saves
2. **Use descriptive names:** Makes it easier to find later
3. **Review before committing:** Check for sensitive data
4. **Use private repos:** For work or personal conversations
5. **Search is powerful:** Use GitHub/GitLab search to find old conversations

## Troubleshooting

**Git not found:**
- Install from https://git-scm.com/download/win
- Restart terminal after installation

**Can't push to GitHub:**
- Check your internet connection
- Verify repository URL is correct
- You may need to authenticate (GitHub will guide you)

**Files too large:**
- Git is best for text/code
- Use OneDrive/Google Drive for large files

## Next Steps

1. Run `setup-git-backup.bat` to set up online backup
2. Try `save-conversation.bat` to save your first conversation
3. Your data is now safe! ðŸŽ‰

{"codeResults":[{"codeBlock":{"relativeWorkspacePath":"CURSOR_INTEGRATION_GUIDE.md","range":{"startPosition":{"line":1,"column":1},"endPosition":{"line":68,"column":1}},"contents":"# Cursor Direct Integration Guide

## ðŸŽ¯ Automatic Conversation Backup - No Manual Work!

Yes! You can integrate directly with Cursor to automatically save ALL conversations without any manual copying!

## Method 1: SpecStory Extension (Recommended - Fully Automatic)

### What is SpecStory?
SpecStory is a Cursor extension that **automatically saves all your chat conversations** to a `.specstory` folder in your project. No manual copying needed!

### Installation Steps:

1. **Open Cursor**
2. **Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`** (Command Palette)
3. **Type:** `Extensions: Install Extension`
4. **Search for:** `SpecStory` or `specstory`
5. **Click Install**

   **OR** install manually:
   - Download from: https://github.com/specstory/specstory-vscode/releases
   - Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`
   - Type: `Extensions: Install from VSIX...`
   - Select the downloaded `.vsix` file

### How It Works:

- âœ… **Automatic:** Every conversation is saved automatically
- âœ… **No manual work:** Just chat normally, everything is saved
- âœ… **Markdown format:** Easy to read and search
- âœ… **Project-based:** Conversations saved per project

### After Installation:

1. **SpecStory automatically creates** `.specstory` folder in your project
2. **All conversations are saved** as markdown files
3. **Run `auto-backup-cursor.bat`** to backup to git
4. **That's it!** No more manual copying!

---

## Method 2: Cursor Convo Export Extension

### Installation:
1. Open Cursor
2. Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`
3. Search for: `Cursor Convo Export`
4. Install the extension

### Features:
- Export conversations via Command Palette
- Save as timestamped files
- Multiple export formats

---

## Method 3: Pieces Integration (Advanced)

Pieces provides AI-powered workflow memory:
- Real-time access to conversation history
- Project-aware context
- Long-term memory for coding assistance

**Installation:** https://pieces.app/learn/ai-connector/cursor

---

- Verify remote is set: `git remote -v`

## Privacy & Security

- **Private Repos:** Use private GitHub/GitLab repos for sensitive conversations
- **Review Before Commit:** Check `.specstory` folder before committing
- **Local Only:** You can use git locally without pushing online

off
REM Automated Cursor Conversation Backup Setup
REM This sets up automatic backup of Cursor conversations using SpecStory extension
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

echo ========================================
echo Cursor Automatic Conversation Backup Setup
echo ========================================
echo.
echo This will set up automatic backup of ALL your Cursor conversations!
echo.

REM Create conversation-logs directory
if not exist "conversation-logs" mkdir conversation-logs
if not exist "conversation-logs\.specstory" mkdir conversation-logs\.specstory

echo Step 1: Install SpecStory Extension
echo ----------------------------------------
echo.
echo SpecStory automatically saves all Cursor conversations to .specstory folder
echo.
echo To install:
echo 1. Open Cursor
echo 2. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Command Palette)
echo 3. Type: Extensions: Install from VSIX...
echo 4. Download SpecStory from: https://github.com/specstory/specstory-vscode/releases
echo    OR search for "SpecStory" in Cursor's extension marketplace
echo.

pause

if errorlevel 1 (

    set /p gitname="Enter your name for git commits: "
    set /p gitemail="Enter your email for git commits: "
    git config user.name "!gitname!"
    git config user.email "!gitemail!"
    echo Git user configured.
    echo.
)

REM Check for remote
git remote -v >nul 2>&1

pause

    git config user.name "!gitname!"
    git config user.email "!gitemail!"
    echo Git user configured.
    echo.
)

REM Check for remote
git remote -v >nul 2>&1

## Quick Start

Yes, you can store all your conversations! Here's how:

### Option 1: Quick Save (Easiest)
1. After an important conversation, run: `quick-save.bat`
2. Paste your conversation notes
3. Press Ctrl+Z and Enter
4. Done! File saved in `conversation-logs/` folder

### Option 2: Full Backup with Git (Recommended)
1. **First time setup:**
   - Run `setup-git-backup.bat`
   - Follow the prompts to connect to GitHub/GitLab
   
2. **After conversations:**
   - Run `save-conversation.bat`
   - Enter a description
   - Paste your notes
   - It will automatically commit to git and push online

## What Gets Saved?

- All conversation logs go to `conversation-logs/` folder
- Files are named with date/time: `YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-SS-description.md`
- Everything is stored in markdown format (easy to read and search)

## Online Backup Options

### GitHub (Free, Recommended)
1. Create account at https://github.com
2. Create new repository (make it private if you want)
3. Run `setup-git-backup.bat` and paste your repo URL
4. All conversations will be backed up online automatically

### GitLab (Free Alternative)
- Similar to GitHub
- Good for private repositories
- Run `setup-git-backup.bat` and choose option 2

### OneDrive/Google Drive (Already Available)
- Just copy the `conversation-logs` folder to your cloud drive
- Simple file sync, no git needed

## Manual Git Commands

If you prefer manual control:

```powershell
# Add conversation logs
git add conversation-logs/

# Commit
git commit -m "Save conversation about [topic]"

# Push to online backup
git push
```

## Privacy & Security

- **Public repositories:** Anyone can see your conversations
- **Private repositories:** Only you can see (recommended for sensitive data)
- Review conversations before committing if they contain sensitive info

## File Structure

```
Desktop/

FQC App - Data Storage Format & Structure

## ðŸ“Š **STORAGE FORMAT: SQLite Database (Room ORM)**

The app stores **all data locally** in SQLite using Room persistence library, then optionally syncs to Google Sheets.

**Database Name:** `fqc_database`
**Database Version:** 6
**Location:** Android device internal storage

---

## ðŸ“‹ **DATABASE TABLES (9 Total)**

### 1. **`test_sessions`** - Session Lifecycle Tracking
**Primary Key:** `sessionId` (auto-increment)

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| sessionId | Long (PK) | Auto-generated session ID |
| serialNumber | String | Device serial number |
| operatorName | String | Operator who started session |
| operatorPin | String | Operator PIN |
| startTimestamp | String | ISO format: "2025-01-14 09:30:00" |
| endTimestamp | String? | ISO format (nullable) |
| status | String | "IN_PROGRESS", "COMPLETED", "INCOMPLETE", "HANDED_OVER" |
| handedOverTo | String? | New operator if handed over |
| handedOverAt | String? | Handover timestamp |
| notes | String | Additional notes |
| hasTestSubmission | Boolean | True if test result was submitted |
| needsSync | Boolean | True if needs Google Sheets sync |
| lastSyncTimestamp | Long | Epoch milliseconds |

**Example:**
```kotlin
TestSession(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    operatorName = "John Doe",
    operatorPin = "1234",
    startTimestamp = "2025-01-14 09:00:00",
    status = "IN_PROGRESS",
    hasTestSubmission = false,
    needsSync = true
)
```

---

### 2. **`frequency_tests`** - Frequency Test Results
**Primary Key:** `testId` (auto-increment)
**Index:** `serialNumber`

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| testId | Long (PK) | Auto-generated test ID |
| serialNumber | String | Device serial |
| operatorName | String | Who ran the test |
| startFreq | Double | Starting frequency (Hz) |
| endFreq | Double | Ending frequency (Hz) |

off
REM Auto-backup script for Cursor conversations
REM This script backs up conversations saved by SpecStory extension
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

echo ========================================
echo Cursor Conversation Auto-Backup
echo ========================================
echo.

REM Check if .specstory folder exists (created by SpecStory extension)
if exist ".specstory" (
    echo Found SpecStory conversations folder!
    echo Backing up conversations...
    echo.
    
    REM Add all conversation files
    git add .specstory/ 2>nul
    git add conversation-logs/ 2>nul
    
    REM Check if there are changes
    git diff --cached --quiet
    if errorlevel 1 (
        echo Committing changes...
        git commit -m "Auto-backup: Cursor conversations - %date% %time%" 2>nul
        
        REM Check if remote exists
        git remote -v >nul 2>&1
        if not errorlevel 1 (
            echo Pushing to remote repository...
            git push 2>nul
            if errorlevel 1 (
                echo Warning: Could not push to remote. Check your connection.
            ) else (
                echo Successfully pushed to remote!
            )
        ) else (
            echo No remote repository configured. Run 'setup-git-backup.bat' to set one up.
        )
        
        echo Backup complete!
    ) else (
        echo No new conversations to backup.
    )
) else (
    echo.
    echo SpecStory extension not detected!
    echo.
    echo To enable automatic conversation saving:
    echo 1. Install SpecStory extension in Cursor
    echo 2. Press Ctrl+Shift+P in Cursor
    echo 3. Search for "SpecStory" and install
    echo.
    echo After installation, SpecStory will automatically save all conversations
    echo to the .specstory folder, and this script will back them up!
    echo.
)

echo.
pause

    if errorlevel 1 (
        echo Committing changes...
        git commit -m "Auto-backup: Cursor conversations - %date% %time%" 2>nul
        
        REM Check if remote exists
        git remote -v >nul 2>&1
        if not errorlevel 1 (
            echo Pushing to remote repository...
            git push 2>nul
            if errorlevel 1 (
                echo Warning: Could not push to remote. Check your connection.
            ) else (
                echo Successfully pushed to remote!
            )
        ) else (
            echo No remote repository configured. Run 'setup-git-backup.bat' to set one up.
        )
        
        echo Backup complete!
    ) else (
        echo No new conversations to backup.
    )
) else (
    echo.

    echo To enable automatic conversation saving:
    echo 1. Install SpecStory extension in Cursor

    echo After installation, SpecStory will automatically save all conversations
    echo to the .specstory folder, and this script will back them up!
    echo.
)

echo.
pause

REM Script to save conversation logs to git
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

echo ========================================
echo Conversation Log Backup Tool
echo ========================================
echo.

REM Create conversation-logs directory if it doesn't exist
if not exist "conversation-logs" mkdir conversation-logs

REM Get current date and time for filename
for /f "tokens=2 delims==" %%I in ('wmic os get localdatetime /value') do set datetime=%%I
set datepart=!datetime:~0,8!
set timepart=!datetime:~8,6!
set timepart=!timepart:~0,2!-!timepart:~2,2!-!timepart:~4,2!

REM Prompt for conversation description
set /p description="Enter a brief description for this conversation (e.g., 'erpnext-setup', 'bug-fix'): "
if "!description!"=="" set description=conversation

REM Create filename
set filename=conversation-logs\%datepart%-%timepart%-%description%.md

echo.
echo Creating conversation log: %filename%
echo.
echo Please paste or type your conversation notes below.
echo Press Enter after each line, then press Ctrl+Z and Enter when done:
echo.

REM Create file with header
(
    echo # Conversation Log - %datepart% %timepart:~0,2%:%timepart:~3,2%:%timepart:~6,2%
    echo.
    echo **Description:** %description%
    echo **Date:** %datepart%
    echo **Time:** %timepart:~0,2%:%timepart:~3,2%:%timepart:~6,2%
    echo.
    echo ---
    echo.
) > "%filename%"

REM Append user input
type con >> "%filename%" 2>nul
if errorlevel 1 (
    echo.
    echo No input detected. Opening file for manual editing...
    echo Please add your conversation notes to: %filename%
    pause
    notepad "%filename%"
)

echo.
echo File saved: %filename%
echo.

REM Ask if user wants to commit to git
set /p commit="Commit to git? (y/n): "

### Step 1: Install SpecStory Extension
Follow the installation steps above.

### Step 2: Run Setup Script
```powershell
.\setup-cursor-auto-backup.bat
```

This will:
- Configure git (if needed)
- Set up remote repository (GitHub/GitLab)
- Create auto-backup script

### Step 3: Automatic Backup Options

#### Option A: Manual Backup (Run when needed)
```powershell
.\auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

#### Option B: Scheduled Backup (Automatic every hour)
```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
```

#### Option C: Git Hook (Backup on every commit)
Create `.git/hooks/post-commit`:
```bash
#!/bin/sh
./auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

How to Add OpenAI API Key to Cursor - Complete Guide

## Method 1: Using Cursor Settings UI (Recommended)

1. **Open Cursor Settings:**
   - Press `Ctrl + ,` (or `Cmd + ,` on Mac)
   - OR go to: **File â†’ Preferences â†’ Settings**

2. **Navigate to AI/Model Settings:**
   - In the settings search bar, type: `openai` or `api key`
   - Look for settings like:
     - `cursor.general.openaiApiKey`
     - `cursor.chat.openaiApiKey`
     - `cursor.composer.openaiApiKey`

3. **Enter Your API Key:**
   - Paste your OpenAI API key (starts with `sk-`)
   - Make sure there are NO extra spaces before or after the key
   - Click "Save" or the settings will auto-save

4. **Restart Cursor:**
   - Close and reopen Cursor completely
   - This ensures the new API key is loaded

## Method 2: Using Command Palette

1. Press `Ctrl + Shift + P` (or `Cmd + Shift + P` on Mac)
2. Type: `Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)`
3. Add this line to your settings.json:
   ```json
   "cursor.general.openaiApiKey": "sk-your-api-key-here"
   ```
4. Save the file and restart Cursor

## Method 3: Environment Variable (Alternative)

1. **Set Environment Variable:**
   - Open PowerShell as Administrator
   - Run: `[System.Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable('OPENAI_API_KEY', 'sk-your-key-here', 'User')`
   - OR manually add it in Windows Environment Variables:
     - Right-click "This PC" â†’ Properties â†’ Advanced System Settings â†’ Environment Variables
     - Add new User variable: `OPENAI_API_KEY` = `sk-your-key-here`

2. **Restart Cursor** after setting the environment variable

## Common Problems & Solutions

### Problem 1: "API Key Not Found" or "Invalid API Key"
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Verify your API key at: https://platform.openai.com/api-keys
- âœ… Make sure the key starts with `sk-`
- âœ… Check for extra spaces or line breaks when copying
- âœ… Ensure you're using the correct key (not a test key or expired key)

   - Look for settings like:
     - `cursor.general.openaiApiKey`
     - `cursor.chat.openaiApiKey`

   - Paste your OpenAI API key (starts with `sk-`)

## Method 2: Using Command Palette

## Method 3: Environment Variable (Alternative)

1. **Set Environment Variable:**
   - Open PowerShell as Administrator

   - OR manually add it in Windows Environment Variables:
     - Right-click "This PC" â†’ Properties â†’ Advanced System Settings â†’ Environment Variables
     - Add new User variable: `OPENAI_API_KEY` = `sk-your-key-here`

2. **Restart Cursor** after setting the environment variable

Since you already have GitHub, here's the fastest way to set everything up:

## ðŸš€ Quick Setup (3 Steps)

### Step 1: Install SpecStory Extension in Cursor
1. Open Cursor
2. Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`
3. Type: `Extensions: Install Extension`
4. Search for: **SpecStory**
5. Click Install

**This automatically saves ALL your conversations!** No manual copying needed.

### Step 2: Create GitHub Repository
1. Go to: https://github.com/new
2. Repository name: `cursor-conversations` (or any name you like)
3. Choose: **Private** (recommended for conversations)
4. **Don't** check "Initialize with README"
5. Click "Create repository"

### Step 3: Connect to GitHub
Run this script:
```powershell
.\connect-to-github.bat
```

When prompted, paste your GitHub repository URL (from step 2).

**That's it!** ðŸŽ‰

---

## How It Works Now

1. **You chat in Cursor** â†’ SpecStory automatically saves to `.specstory/` folder
2. **Run backup script** â†’ `auto-backup-cursor.bat` commits and pushes to GitHub
3. **Everything is backed up online!** âœ…

---

## Daily Usage

After chatting in Cursor, just run:
```powershell
.\auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

This will:
- âœ… Commit all new conversations
- âœ… Push to GitHub automatically
- âœ… Keep everything backed up online

---

## Optional: Automatic Backup Every Hour

To automatically backup every hour without running the script:

```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
```

---

## Your GitHub Repository

After setup, you can view all your conversations at:
`https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/YOUR_REPO_NAME`

All conversations are saved as markdown files, easy to read and search!

---

## Need Help?

- **Can't push?** GitHub might ask you to authenticate - just follow the prompts
- **SpecStory not working?** Make sure extension is installed and enabled

1. Go to: https://github.com/new
2. Repository name: `cursor-conversations` (or any name you like)
3. Choose: **Private** (recommended for conversations)
4. **Don't** check "Initialize with README"
5. Click "Create repository"

### Step 3: Connect to GitHub
Run this script:
```powershell
.\connect-to-github.bat
```

When prompted, paste your GitHub repository URL (from step 2).

**That's it!** ðŸŽ‰

---

## How It Works Now

1. **You chat in Cursor** â†’ SpecStory automatically saves to `.specstory/` folder
2. **Run backup script** â†’ `auto-backup-cursor.bat` commits and pushes to GitHub
3. **Everything is backed up online!** âœ…

---

## Daily Usage

After chatting in Cursor, just run:
```powershell
.\auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

This will:
- âœ… Commit all new conversations
- âœ… Push to GitHub automatically
- âœ… Keep everything backed up online

---

## Optional: Automatic Backup Every Hour

To automatically backup every hour without running the script:

```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
```

---

## Your GitHub Repository

After setup, you can view all your conversations at:
`https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/YOUR_REPO_NAME`

All conversations are saved as markdown files, easy to read and search!

---

## Need Help?

- **SpecStory not working?** Make sure extension is installed and enabled

FQC Data Storage Structure - Example Files

## ðŸ“ Files Created

1. **example_sqlite_data.sql** - Complete SQLite database schema with example data
2. **example_google_sheets_structure.csv** - Google Sheets layout with example data
3. **This README** - Explanation of the data structure

---

## ðŸ“Š Example Scenario

**Device:** SLC251EG000123 (Ember Gray)  
**Operator:** John Doe  
**Journey:**

```
08:30 â†’ Device Created
09:00 â†’ Frequency Test #1 â†’ âŒ FAILED (Right to left shift, Wire sound)
09:20 â†’ Rework: Driver INTERCHANGE (45 min)
10:30 â†’ Frequency Test #2 â†’ âœ… PASSED
11:00 â†’ Song Test #1 â†’ âŒ FAILED (Bass distortion)
11:25 â†’ Rework: HEADBAND CHANGE (90 min)
14:00 â†’ Complete QC + FQC â†’ âœ… PASSED
16:45 â†’ Device Shipped
```

---

## ðŸ—„ï¸ SQLite Database Structure (9 Tables)

### 1. **devices** - Master device list
- Serial Number (PK)
- MAC ID
- Color, Status, Iterations
- Final Result

### 2. **operators** - Worker information
- Operator ID (PK)
- Name, Devices handled
- Work hours, Efficiency

### 3. **sessions** - Every work session
- Session ID (PK)
- Links: Serial Number, Operator
- Type, Duration, Status changes

### 4. **frequency_tests** - All frequency tests
- Test ID (PK)
- Parameters: Start/End Hz, Duration
- Balance, Loop settings
- Result, Issues, Solutions
- **Iteration Number** (tracks attempts)

### 5. **song_tests** - All song tests
- Test ID (PK)
- Songs played, Volume, Balance
- Result, Issues, Remarks
- **Iteration Number**

### 6. **fqc_records** - Final Quality Checks
- FQC ID (PK)
- 11 checklist items (PASS/FAIL)
- Images (base64), Descriptions
- Auto-pulled previous test results
- **Iteration Number**

### 7. **rework_history** - All repairs/fixes
- Rework ID (PK)
- Reason, Failed test type
- Actions taken, Time to repair
- **Iteration Number**

### 8. **performance_metrics** - Daily stats
- Calculated per operator/day

**Solutions:**
- âœ… Check your OpenAI account balance: https://platform.openai.com/account/billing
- âœ… Add payment method if needed
- âœ… Verify your account has available credits

### Problem 3: "Network Error" or "Connection Failed"
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Check your internet connection
- âœ… Verify firewall/antivirus isn't blocking Cursor
- âœ… Try disabling VPN if you're using one
- âœ… Check if OpenAI API is accessible: https://status.openai.com/

### Problem 4: API Key Works in Browser but Not in Cursor
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Restart Cursor completely (close all windows)
- âœ… Clear Cursor cache:
   - Close Cursor
   - Delete: `%APPDATA%\Cursor\Cache`
   - Restart Cursor
- âœ… Check if you have multiple Cursor installations conflicting

### Problem 5: Settings Not Saving
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Make sure Cursor has write permissions to settings file
- âœ… Check if settings.json is read-only
- âœ… Try running Cursor as Administrator (temporarily)
- âœ… Check disk space availability

## Verification Steps

1. **Test the API Key:**
   - Open Cursor Chat (usually `Ctrl + L` or `Cmd + L`)
   - Ask a simple question like "Hello, can you hear me?"
   - If it responds, your API key is working!

2. **Check API Usage:**
   - Visit: https://platform.openai.com/usage
   - You should see API calls being made when using Cursor

3. **Check Cursor Logs:**
   - Open Command Palette (`Ctrl + Shift + P`)
   - Type: `Developer: Toggle Developer Tools`
   - Check Console for any API-related errors

## Your Current Settings Location

Your Cursor settings are located at:
```
C:\Users\pc\AppData\Roaming\Cursor\User\settings.json
```

## Quick Fix Checklist

- [ ] API key copied correctly (starts with `sk-`)
- [ ] No extra spaces in the API key
- [ ] OpenAI account has credits/active billing
- [ ] Cursor restarted after adding key
- [ ] Internet connection is working

### Images Array (Base64)

## ðŸ” **QUERY EXAMPLES**

### Get all tests for a device
```kotlin
val frequencyTests = database.frequencyTestDao()
    .getAllFrequencyTests()
    .filter { it.serialNumber == serialNumber }

val songTests = database.songTestDao()
    .getAllSongTests()
    .filter { it.serialNumber == serialNumber }
```

### Get unsynced data
```kotlin
val unsyncedFreq = database.frequencyTestDao()
    .getUnsyncedFrequencyTests(serialNumber)

val unsyncedSongs = database.songTestDao()
    .getUnsyncedSongTests(serialNumber)
```

### Get device history
```kotlin
val sessions = database.testSessionDao()
    .getSessionsForDevice(serialNumber)

val device = database.deviceDao()
    .getDevice(serialNumber)
```

---

## âœ… **Summary**

**Storage Format:** SQLite (Room ORM)
**Database Name:** `fqc_database`
**Total Tables:** 9 (4 main + 5 auxiliary)
**Primary Data:** Test results, sessions, devices, operators
**Sync Target:** Google Sheets (optional)
**Timestamp Format:** ISO format strings and Unix epoch milliseconds

All data is stored locally first, then synced to Google Sheets when:
- Network is available
- Data has `needsSync = true` flag
- Manual sync is triggered or periodic sync runs

Cursor Direct Integration Guide

## ðŸŽ¯ Automatic Conversation Backup - No Manual Work!

Yes! You can integrate directly with Cursor to automatically save ALL conversations without any manual copying!

## Method 1: SpecStory Extension (Recommended - Fully Automatic)

### What is SpecStory?
SpecStory is a Cursor extension that **automatically saves all your chat conversations** to a `.specstory` folder in your project. No manual copying needed!

### Installation Steps:

1. **Open Cursor**
2. **Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`** (Command Palette)
3. **Type:** `Extensions: Install Extension`
4. **Search for:** `SpecStory` or `specstory`
5. **Click Install**

   **OR** install manually:
   - Download from: https://github.com/specstory/specstory-vscode/releases
   - Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`
   - Type: `Extensions: Install from VSIX...`
   - Select the downloaded `.vsix` file

### How It Works:

- âœ… **Automatic:** Every conversation is saved automatically
- âœ… **No manual work:** Just chat normally, everything is saved
- âœ… **Markdown format:** Easy to read and search
- âœ… **Project-based:** Conversations saved per project

### After Installation:

1. **SpecStory automatically creates** `.specstory` folder in your project
2. **All conversations are saved** as markdown files
3. **Run `auto-backup-cursor.bat`** to backup to git
4. **That's it!** No more manual copying!

---

## Method 2: Cursor Convo Export Extension

### Installation:
1. Open Cursor
2. Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`
3. Search for: `Cursor Convo Export`
4. Install the extension

### Features:
- Export conversations via Command Palette
- Save as timestamped files
- Multiple export formats

---

## Method 3: Pieces Integration (Advanced)

Pieces provides AI-powered workflow memory:
- Real-time access to conversation history
- Project-aware context
- Long-term memory for coding assistance

**Installation:** https://pieces.app/learn/ai-connector/cursor

---

## Complete Setup (SpecStory + Git Backup)

### Step 1: Install SpecStory Extension
Follow the installation steps above.

### Step 2: Run Setup Script
```powershell
.\setup-cursor-auto-backup.bat
```

This will:
- Configure git (if needed)
- Set up remote repository (GitHub/GitLab)
- Create auto-backup script

### Step 3: Automatic Backup Options

#### Option A: Manual Backup (Run when needed)
```powershell
.\auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

#### Option B: Scheduled Backup (Automatic every hour)
```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
```

#### Option C: Git Hook (Backup on every commit)
Create `.git/hooks/post-commit`:
```bash
#!/bin/sh
./auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

---

## Troubleshooting

### SpecStory not saving conversations?
- Make sure extension is installed and enabled
- Check if `.specstory` folder is created
- Restart Cursor after installation

### Auto-backup not working?
- Check if git is initialized: `git status`
- Verify remote is set: `git remote -v`
- Run `auto-backup-cursor.bat` manually to see errors

### Can't push to GitHub?
- Check internet connection
- Verify repository URL: `git remote -v`
- You may need to authenticate (GitHub will prompt you)

---

## Privacy & Security

- **Private Repos:** Use private GitHub/GitLab repos for sensitive conversations
- **Review Before Commit:** Check `.specstory` folder before committing
- **Local Only:** You can use git locally without pushing online

","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"setup-cursor-auto-backup.bat","contents":"@echo off
REM Automated Cursor Conversation Backup Setup
REM This sets up automatic backup of Cursor conversations using SpecStory extension
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

echo ========================================
echo Cursor Automatic Conversation Backup Setup
echo ========================================
echo.
echo This will set up automatic backup of ALL your Cursor conversations!
echo.

REM Create conversation-logs directory
if not exist "conversation-logs" mkdir conversation-logs
if not exist "conversation-logs\.specstory" mkdir conversation-logs\.specstory

echo Step 1: Install SpecStory Extension
echo ----------------------------------------
echo.
echo SpecStory automatically saves all Cursor conversations to .specstory folder
echo.
echo To install:
echo 1. Open Cursor
echo 2. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Command Palette)
echo 3. Type: Extensions: Install from VSIX...
echo 4. Download SpecStory from: https://github.com/specstory/specstory-vscode/releases
echo    OR search for "SpecStory" in Cursor's extension marketplace
echo.
echo After installation, SpecStory will automatically save all conversations!
echo.

pause

echo.
echo Step 2: Set up Git Backup
echo ----------------------------------------
echo.

REM Check if git is configured
git config user.name >nul 2>&1
if errorlevel 1 (
    echo Git user not configured. Setting up...
    set /p gitname="Enter your name for git commits: "
    set /p gitemail="Enter your email for git commits: "
    git config user.name "!gitname!"
    git config user.email "!gitemail!"
    echo Git user configured.
    echo.
)

REM Check for remote
git remote -v >nul 2>&1
if errorlevel 1 (
    echo No remote repository configured.
    set /p setup_remote="Set up GitHub/GitLab backup now? (y/n): "
    if /i "!setup_remote!"=="y" (
        echo.
        echo 1. Create a repository on GitHub/GitLab
        echo 2. Copy the repository URL
        echo.
        set /p repo_url="Enter repository URL: "
        if not "!repo_url!"=="" (
            git remote add origin "!repo_url!"
            echo Remote added!
        )
    )
)

echo.
echo Step 3: Create Auto-Backup Script
echo ----------------------------------------
echo.

REM Create the auto-backup script
(
echo @echo off
echo REM Auto-backup script for Cursor conversations
echo setlocal enabledelayedexpansion
echo.
echo REM Check if .specstory folder exists in current directory
echo if exist ".specstory" (
echo     echo Found .specstory folder, backing up conversations...
echo     git add .specstory/
echo     git add conversation-logs/
echo     git commit -m "Auto-backup: Cursor conversations - %date% %time%" 2^>nul
echo     git push 2^>nul
echo     echo Backup complete!
echo ^) else (
echo     echo No .specstory folder found. Make sure SpecStory extension is installed.
echo ^)
) > auto-backup-cursor.bat

echo Created: auto-backup-cursor.bat
echo.

echo Step 4: Set up Scheduled Backup (Optional)
echo ----------------------------------------
echo.
set /p schedule="Set up automatic backup every hour? (y/n): "
if /i "!schedule!"=="y" (
    echo.
    echo Creating scheduled task...
    echo This will run auto-backup-cursor.bat every hour.
    echo.
    
    REM Create a PowerShell script for scheduled task
    (
        echo $action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute "%~dp0auto-backup-cursor.bat"
        echo $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -Once -At ^(Get-Date^) -RepetitionInterval ^(New-TimeSpan -Hours 1^) -RepetitionDuration ^([TimeSpan]::MaxValue^)
        echo $principal = New-ScheduledTaskPrincipal -UserId "$env:USERNAME" -LogonType Interactive
        echo Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName "Cursor Conversation Backup" -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -Principal $principal -Description "Automatically backs up Cursor conversations every hour"
        echo Write-Host "Scheduled task created! Backups will run every hour."
    ) > setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
    
    echo Created: setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
    echo.
    echo To enable scheduled backups, run:
    echo   powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
    echo.
)

echo.
echo ========================================
echo Setup Complete!
echo ========================================
echo.
echo What happens now:
echo 1. SpecStory extension saves all conversations to .specstory folder
echo 2. Run 'auto-backup-cursor.bat' anytime to backup to git
echo 3. Conversations are automatically saved and can be pushed online
echo.
echo Manual backup: Run 'auto-backup-cursor.bat'
echo Automatic backup: Set up scheduled task (see above)
echo.
pause

## Quick Start

Yes, you can store all your conversations! Here's how:

### Option 1: Quick Save (Easiest)
1. After an important conversation, run: `quick-save.bat`
2. Paste your conversation notes
3. Press Ctrl+Z and Enter
4. Done! File saved in `conversation-logs/` folder

### Option 2: Full Backup with Git (Recommended)
1. **First time setup:**
   - Run `setup-git-backup.bat`
   - Follow the prompts to connect to GitHub/GitLab
   
2. **After conversations:**
   - Run `save-conversation.bat`
   - Enter a description
   - Paste your notes
   - It will automatically commit to git and push online

## What Gets Saved?

- All conversation logs go to `conversation-logs/` folder
- Files are named with date/time: `YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-SS-description.md`
- Everything is stored in markdown format (easy to read and search)

## Online Backup Options

### GitHub (Free, Recommended)
1. Create account at https://github.com
2. Create new repository (make it private if you want)
3. Run `setup-git-backup.bat` and paste your repo URL
4. All conversations will be backed up online automatically

### GitLab (Free Alternative)
- Similar to GitHub
- Good for private repositories
- Run `setup-git-backup.bat` and choose option 2

### OneDrive/Google Drive (Already Available)
- Just copy the `conversation-logs` folder to your cloud drive
- Simple file sync, no git needed

## Manual Git Commands

If you prefer manual control:

```powershell
# Add conversation logs
git add conversation-logs/

# Commit
git commit -m "Save conversation about [topic]"

# Push to online backup
git push
```

## Privacy & Security

- **Public repositories:** Anyone can see your conversations
- **Private repositories:** Only you can see (recommended for sensitive data)
- Review conversations before committing if they contain sensitive info

## File Structure

```
Desktop/
â”œâ”€â”€ conversation-logs/          # All your conversation logs
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ README.md              # Instructions
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 2025-01-20-14-30-00-erpnext-setup.md
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ 2025-01-20-15-45-00-bug-fix.md
â”œâ”€â”€ save-conversation.bat      # Main save script
â”œâ”€â”€ setup-git-backup.bat       # One-time setup
â””â”€â”€ quick-save.bat            # Quick save script
```

## Tips

1. **Save regularly:** Don't wait too long between saves
2. **Use descriptive names:** Makes it easier to find later
3. **Review before committing:** Check for sensitive data
4. **Use private repos:** For work or personal conversations
5. **Search is powerful:** Use GitHub/GitLab search to find old conversations

## Troubleshooting

**Git not found:**
- Install from https://git-scm.com/download/win
- Restart terminal after installation

**Can't push to GitHub:**
- Check your internet connection
- Verify repository URL is correct
- You may need to authenticate (GitHub will guide you)

**Files too large:**
- Git is best for text/code
- Use OneDrive/Google Drive for large files

## Next Steps

1. Run `setup-git-backup.bat` to set up online backup
2. Try `save-conversation.bat` to save your first conversation
3. Your data is now safe! ðŸŽ‰








































","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"DATA_STORAGE_FORMAT.md","contents":"# FQC App - Data Storage Format & Structure

## ðŸ“Š **STORAGE FORMAT: SQLite Database (Room ORM)**

The app stores **all data locally** in SQLite using Room persistence library, then optionally syncs to Google Sheets.

**Database Name:** `fqc_database`
**Database Version:** 6
**Location:** Android device internal storage

---

## ðŸ“‹ **DATABASE TABLES (9 Total)**

### 1. **`test_sessions`** - Session Lifecycle Tracking
**Primary Key:** `sessionId` (auto-increment)

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| sessionId | Long (PK) | Auto-generated session ID |
| serialNumber | String | Device serial number |
| operatorName | String | Operator who started session |
| operatorPin | String | Operator PIN |
| startTimestamp | String | ISO format: "2025-01-14 09:30:00" |
| endTimestamp | String? | ISO format (nullable) |
| status | String | "IN_PROGRESS", "COMPLETED", "INCOMPLETE", "HANDED_OVER" |
| handedOverTo | String? | New operator if handed over |
| handedOverAt | String? | Handover timestamp |
| notes | String | Additional notes |
| hasTestSubmission | Boolean | True if test result was submitted |
| needsSync | Boolean | True if needs Google Sheets sync |
| lastSyncTimestamp | Long | Epoch milliseconds |

**Example:**
```kotlin
TestSession(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    operatorName = "John Doe",
    operatorPin = "1234",
    startTimestamp = "2025-01-14 09:00:00",
    status = "IN_PROGRESS",
    hasTestSubmission = false,
    needsSync = true
)
```

---

### 2. **`frequency_tests`** - Frequency Test Results
**Primary Key:** `testId` (auto-increment)
**Index:** `serialNumber`

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| testId | Long (PK) | Auto-generated test ID |
| serialNumber | String | Device serial |
| operatorName | String | Who ran the test |
| startFreq | Double | Starting frequency (Hz) |
| endFreq | Double | Ending frequency (Hz) |
| duration | Double | Test duration (seconds) |
| balance | Float | Audio balance (0-100) |
| issues | String | JSON array: `["Right to left shift","Wire sound"]` |
| solutions | String | JSON array: `["INTERCHANGE"]` |
| remark | String | Free text remark |
| result | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| timestamp | String | ISO format: "2025-01-14 09:10:00" |
| iterationNumber | Int | Which attempt (1, 2, 3...) |
| startTimestamp | String | Test start time |
| endTimestamp | String | Test end time |
| needsSync | Boolean | Sync flag |
| lastSyncTimestamp | Long | Sync timestamp |

**Example:**
```kotlin
FrequencyTest(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    operatorName = "John Doe",
    startFreq = 20.0,
    endFreq = 20000.0,
    duration = 600.0,  // 10 minutes
    balance = 50.0f,
    issues = """["Right to left shift","Wire sound"]""",
    solutions = """["INTERCHANGE"]""",
    remark = "Noticeable shift detected",
    result = "FAIL",
    timestamp = "2025-01-14 09:15:00",
    iterationNumber = 1
)
```

---

### 3. **`song_tests`** - Song Test Results
**Primary Key:** `testId` (auto-increment)
**Index:** `serialNumber`

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| testId | Long (PK) | Auto-generated test ID |
| serialNumber | String | Device serial |
| operatorName | String | Who ran the test |
| songName | String | Song identifier (e.g., "Song 1", "OVERALL_REVIEW") |
| result | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| issues | String | JSON array or plain text |
| remark | String | Free text remark |
| timestamp | String | ISO format |
| testIterationNumber | Int | Which test attempt |
| isOverallResult | Boolean | True if overall review |
| needsSync | Boolean | Sync flag |
| lastSyncTimestamp | Long | Sync timestamp |

**Example:**
```kotlin
SongTest(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    operatorName = "John Doe",
    songName = "OVERALL_HEADPHONE_REVIEW",
    result = "FAIL",
    issues = "Bass distortion at high volume",
    remark = "Distortion in bass-heavy tracks",
    timestamp = "2025-01-14 11:10:00",
    testIterationNumber = 1,
    isOverallResult = true
)
```

---

### 4. **`fqc_records`** - Final Quality Control Records
**Primary Key:** `fqcId` (auto-increment)
**Index:** `serialNumber`

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| fqcId | Long (PK) | Auto-generated FQC ID |
| serialNumber | String | Device serial |
| operatorName | String | Who performed FQC |
| timestamp | String | ISO format |
| fqcType | String | "INITIAL", "REWORK", "FINAL_PASS" |
| plasticCosmetics | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| modeSelector | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| button | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| slider | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| headbandScratch | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| headbandShape | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| screwBush | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| ledCheck | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| acBalance | String | AC driver balance |
| bcBalance | String | BC driver balance |
| serialVerification | String | Serial verification |
| imageCount | Int | Number of photos |
| imagesBase64 | String | JSON array of base64 images |
| imageDescriptions | String | JSON array of descriptions |
| overallResult | String | "PASS" or "FAIL" |
| majorIssues | String | Major issues found |
| remark | String | Free text |
| latestFreqResult | String | Latest frequency test result |
| latestSongResult | String | Latest song test result |
| fqcDurationSec | Int | FQC duration in seconds |
| iterationNumber | Int | Attempt number |
| needsSync | Boolean | Sync flag |
| lastSyncTimestamp | Long | Sync timestamp |

**Example:**
```kotlin
FQCRecord(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    operatorName = "John Doe",
    timestamp = "2025-01-14 14:40:00",
    fqcType = "FINAL_PASS",
    plasticCosmetics = "PASS",
    modeSelector = "PASS",
    button = "PASS",
    slider = "PASS",
    headbandScratch = "PASS",
    headbandShape = "PASS",
    screwBush = "PASS",
    ledCheck = "PASS",
    acBalance = "PASS",
    bcBalance = "PASS",
    serialVerification = "PASS",
    imageCount = 2,
    imagesBase64 = """["base64_image_1","base64_image_2"]""",
    imageDescriptions = """["Headband after replacement","LED check"]""",
    overallResult = "PASS",
    latestFreqResult = "PASS",
    latestSongResult = "PASS",
    fqcDurationSec = 1800
)
```

---

### 5. **`devices`** - Master Device Records
**Primary Key:** `serialNumber`

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| serialNumber | String (PK) | Device serial (primary key) |
| macId | String | MAC address |
| color | String | Device color code |
| createdDate | String | Date created |
| finalStatus | String | "IN_PROGRESS", "PASSED", "FAILED" |
| totalIterations | Int | Total test attempts |
| totalTimeHours | Double | Total testing hours |
| finalOperator | String | Last operator |
| firstTestDate | String | First test date |
| finalShipDate | String | Final ship date |
| needsSync | Boolean | Sync flag |
| lastSyncTimestamp | Long | Sync timestamp |

**Example:**
```kotlin
Device(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    macId = "AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF",
    color = "EG",  // Ember Gray
    createdDate = "2025-01-13",
    finalStatus = "PASSED",
    totalIterations = 3,
    totalTimeHours = 4.5,
    finalOperator = "John Doe",
    firstTestDate = "2025-01-14",
    finalShipDate = "2025-01-14"
)
```

---

### 6. **`operators`** - Operator Records
**Primary Key:** `id` (auto-increment)

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| id | Long (PK) | Auto-generated ID |
| name | String | Operator name |
| createdAt | Long | Epoch milliseconds |

**Example:**
```kotlin
Operator(
    name = "John Doe",
    createdAt = 1705224000000L
)
```

---

### 7. **`mac_id_cache`** - MAC ID Cache
**Primary Key:** `serialNumber`

| Field | Type | Description |
|-------|------|-------------|
| serialNumber | String (PK) | Device serial |
| macAddress | String | MAC address |
| lastUpdated | Long | Last update timestamp |

---

### 8. **`sessions`** - Legacy Session Table (being phased out)
Used for older session tracking logic.

### 9. **`fqc_sessions`** - Legacy FQC Session Table (being phased out)
Used for older session tracking logic.

---

## ðŸ”„ **DATA FLOW**

### 1. **Session Start**
```kotlin
// When operator logs in and connects Bluetooth device
sessionManager.startSession(
    serialNumber = "SLC251EG000123",
    operatorName = "John Doe",
    operatorPin = "1234"
)
```
â†’ Creates `TestSession` with status `IN_PROGRESS`

---

### 2. **Frequency Test**
```kotlin
// After frequency sweep test
val frequencyTest = FrequencyTest(
    serialNumber = currentSerial,
    operatorName = currentOperator,
    startFreq = 20.0,
    endFreq = 20000.0,
    duration = 600.0,
    balance = 50.0f,
    issues = Gson().toJson(selectedIssues),
    solutions = Gson().toJson(selectedSolutions),
    remark = remarkText,
    result = if (pass) "PASS" else "FAIL",
    timestamp = SimpleDateFormat("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss").format(Date()),
    iterationNumber = iterationCount,
    needsSync = true
)

repository.insertFrequencyTest(frequencyTest)
```
â†’ Inserts into `frequency_tests` table

---

### 3. **Song Test**
```kotlin
// After song playback test
val songTest = SongTest(
    serialNumber = currentSerial,
    operatorName = currentOperator,
    songName = songName,
    result = if (passed) "PASS" else "FAIL",
    issues = Gson().toJson(issuesList),
    remark = remarkText,
    timestamp = SimpleDateFormat("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss").format(Date()),
    testIterationNumber = iterationCount,
    isOverallResult = true,
    needsSync = true
)

repository.insertSongTest(songTest)
```
â†’ Inserts into `song_tests` table

---

### 4. **Review Screen Submission**
```kotlin
// When operator submits review
val testResult = TestResult(
    testType = TestType.FREQUENCY,  // or SONG
    outcome = TestOutcome.PASS,     // or FAIL, CAN_BE_PASSED, TEST_NOT_DONE
    issues = selectedIssues,
    solutions = selectedSolutions,
    remark = remarkText
)

// Based on outcome, saves to appropriate table
when (testResult.outcome) {
    TestOutcome.PASS -> // Mark as passed
    TestOutcome.FAIL -> // Mark as failed
    TestOutcome.CAN_BE_PASSED -> // Mark as conditional pass
    TestOutcome.TEST_NOT_DONE -> // Mark as not done
}

sessionManager.markSessionHasSubmission()
```
â†’ Updates `TestSession.hasTestSubmission = true`

---

### 5. **Session End**
```kotlin
// When Bluetooth disconnects or "Forget Device" pressed
sessionManager.endSession(
    reason = "DISCONNECT",
    hasTestSubmission = hasSubmission
)
```
â†’ Updates `TestSession` status to `COMPLETED` or `INCOMPLETE`, sets `endTimestamp`

---

## ðŸ“¤ **SYNC TO GOOGLE SHEETS**

Data marked with `needsSync = true` is uploaded to Google Sheets:

1. **Frequency Tests** â†’ Google Sheets "Frequency Tests" tab
2. **Song Tests** â†’ Google Sheets "Song Tests" tab
3. **FQC Records** â†’ Google Sheets "FQC Records" tab
4. **Devices** â†’ Google Sheets "Devices" tab
5. **Test Sessions** â†’ Google Sheets "Sessions" tab

After successful sync, `needsSync` is set to `false` and `lastSyncTimestamp` is updated.

---

## ðŸ“ **JSON FORMATS**

### Issues Array
```json
["Right to left shift", "Wire sound", "Right Dominent"]
```

### Solutions Array
```json
["INTERCHANGE", "Replace AC Driver", "2dB program"]
```

### Images Array (Base64)
```json
[
  "iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJ...",
  "iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJ..."
]
```

### Image Descriptions Array
```json
["Headband after replacement", "Final LED check"]
```

---

## ðŸ” **QUERY EXAMPLES**

### Get all tests for a device
```kotlin
val frequencyTests = database.frequencyTestDao()
    .getAllFrequencyTests()
    .filter { it.serialNumber == serialNumber }

val songTests = database.songTestDao()
    .getAllSongTests()
    .filter { it.serialNumber == serialNumber }
```

### Get unsynced data
```kotlin
val unsyncedFreq = database.frequencyTestDao()
    .getUnsyncedFrequencyTests(serialNumber)

val unsyncedSongs = database.songTestDao()
    .getUnsyncedSongTests(serialNumber)
```

### Get device history
```kotlin
val sessions = database.testSessionDao()
    .getSessionsForDevice(serialNumber)

val device = database.deviceDao()
    .getDevice(serialNumber)
```

---

## âœ… **Summary**

**Storage Format:** SQLite (Room ORM)
**Database Name:** `fqc_database`
**Total Tables:** 9 (4 main + 5 auxiliary)
**Primary Data:** Test results, sessions, devices, operators
**Sync Target:** Google Sheets (optional)
**Timestamp Format:** ISO format strings and Unix epoch milliseconds

All data is stored locally first, then synced to Google Sheets when:
- Network is available
- Data has `needsSync = true` flag
- Manual sync is triggered or periodic sync runs


","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"auto-backup-cursor.bat","contents":"@echo off
REM Auto-backup script for Cursor conversations
REM This script backs up conversations saved by SpecStory extension
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

echo ========================================
echo Cursor Conversation Auto-Backup
echo ========================================
echo.

REM Check if .specstory folder exists (created by SpecStory extension)
if exist ".specstory" (
    echo Found SpecStory conversations folder!
    echo Backing up conversations...
    echo.
    
    REM Add all conversation files
    git add .specstory/ 2>nul
    git add conversation-logs/ 2>nul
    
    REM Check if there are changes
    git diff --cached --quiet
    if errorlevel 1 (
        echo Committing changes...
        git commit -m "Auto-backup: Cursor conversations - %date% %time%" 2>nul
        
        REM Check if remote exists
        git remote -v >nul 2>&1
        if not errorlevel 1 (
            echo Pushing to remote repository...
            git push 2>nul
            if errorlevel 1 (
                echo Warning: Could not push to remote. Check your connection.
            ) else (
                echo Successfully pushed to remote!
            )
        ) else (
            echo No remote repository configured. Run 'setup-git-backup.bat' to set one up.
        )
        
        echo Backup complete!
    ) else (
        echo No new conversations to backup.
    )
) else (
    echo.
    echo SpecStory extension not detected!
    echo.
    echo To enable automatic conversation saving:
    echo 1. Install SpecStory extension in Cursor
    echo 2. Press Ctrl+Shift+P in Cursor
    echo 3. Search for "SpecStory" and install
    echo.
    echo After installation, SpecStory will automatically save all conversations
    echo to the .specstory folder, and this script will back them up!
    echo.
)

echo.
pause








































","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"save-conversation.bat","contents":"@echo off
REM Script to save conversation logs to git
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

echo ========================================
echo Conversation Log Backup Tool
echo ========================================
echo.

REM Create conversation-logs directory if it doesn't exist
if not exist "conversation-logs" mkdir conversation-logs

REM Get current date and time for filename
for /f "tokens=2 delims==" %%I in ('wmic os get localdatetime /value') do set datetime=%%I
set datepart=!datetime:~0,8!
set timepart=!datetime:~8,6!
set timepart=!timepart:~0,2!-!timepart:~2,2!-!timepart:~4,2!

REM Prompt for conversation description
set /p description="Enter a brief description for this conversation (e.g., 'erpnext-setup', 'bug-fix'): "
if "!description!"=="" set description=conversation

REM Create filename
set filename=conversation-logs\%datepart%-%timepart%-%description%.md

echo.
echo Creating conversation log: %filename%
echo.
echo Please paste or type your conversation notes below.
echo Press Enter after each line, then press Ctrl+Z and Enter when done:
echo.

REM Create file with header
(
    echo # Conversation Log - %datepart% %timepart:~0,2%:%timepart:~3,2%:%timepart:~6,2%
    echo.
    echo **Description:** %description%
    echo **Date:** %datepart%
    echo **Time:** %timepart:~0,2%:%timepart:~3,2%:%timepart:~6,2%
    echo.
    echo ---
    echo.
) > "%filename%"

REM Append user input
type con >> "%filename%" 2>nul
if errorlevel 1 (
    echo.
    echo No input detected. Opening file for manual editing...
    echo Please add your conversation notes to: %filename%
    pause
    notepad "%filename%"
)

echo.
echo File saved: %filename%
echo.

REM Ask if user wants to commit to git
set /p commit="Commit to git? (y/n): "
if /i "!commit!"=="y" (
    echo.
    echo Adding to git...
    git add "%filename%"
    
    REM Check if git is configured
    git config user.name >nul 2>&1
    if errorlevel 1 (
        echo.
        echo Git user not configured. Setting up...
        set /p gitname="Enter your name for git commits: "
        set /p gitemail="Enter your email for git commits: "
        git config user.name "!gitname!"
        git config user.email "!gitemail!"
    )
    
    echo Committing...
    git commit -m "Add conversation log: %description% - %datepart%"
    
    echo.
    echo Checking for remote repository...
    git remote -v >nul 2>&1
    if not errorlevel 1 (
        set /p push="Push to remote repository? (y/n): "
        if /i "!push!"=="y" (
            echo Pushing to remote...
            git push
        )
    ) else (
        echo No remote repository configured.
        echo Run 'setup-git-backup.bat' to set up GitHub backup.
    )
    
    echo.
    echo Done! Conversation saved and committed to git.
) else (
    echo Conversation saved locally. Run 'git add' and 'git commit' manually when ready.
)

echo.
pause








































","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"CURSOR_OPENAI_SETUP_GUIDE.md","contents":"# How to Add OpenAI API Key to Cursor - Complete Guide

## Method 1: Using Cursor Settings UI (Recommended)

1. **Open Cursor Settings:**
   - Press `Ctrl + ,` (or `Cmd + ,` on Mac)
   - OR go to: **File â†’ Preferences â†’ Settings**

2. **Navigate to AI/Model Settings:**
   - In the settings search bar, type: `openai` or `api key`
   - Look for settings like:
     - `cursor.general.openaiApiKey`
     - `cursor.chat.openaiApiKey`
     - `cursor.composer.openaiApiKey`

3. **Enter Your API Key:**
   - Paste your OpenAI API key (starts with `sk-`)
   - Make sure there are NO extra spaces before or after the key
   - Click "Save" or the settings will auto-save

4. **Restart Cursor:**
   - Close and reopen Cursor completely
   - This ensures the new API key is loaded

## Method 2: Using Command Palette

1. Press `Ctrl + Shift + P` (or `Cmd + Shift + P` on Mac)
2. Type: `Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)`
3. Add this line to your settings.json:
   ```json
   "cursor.general.openaiApiKey": "sk-your-api-key-here"
   ```
4. Save the file and restart Cursor

## Method 3: Environment Variable (Alternative)

1. **Set Environment Variable:**
   - Open PowerShell as Administrator
   - Run: `[System.Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable('OPENAI_API_KEY', 'sk-your-key-here', 'User')`
   - OR manually add it in Windows Environment Variables:
     - Right-click "This PC" â†’ Properties â†’ Advanced System Settings â†’ Environment Variables
     - Add new User variable: `OPENAI_API_KEY` = `sk-your-key-here`

2. **Restart Cursor** after setting the environment variable

## Common Problems & Solutions

### Problem 1: "API Key Not Found" or "Invalid API Key"
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Verify your API key at: https://platform.openai.com/api-keys
- âœ… Make sure the key starts with `sk-`
- âœ… Check for extra spaces or line breaks when copying
- âœ… Ensure you're using the correct key (not a test key or expired key)

### Problem 2: "Insufficient Credits" or "Billing Error"
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Check your OpenAI account balance: https://platform.openai.com/account/billing
- âœ… Add payment method if needed
- âœ… Verify your account has available credits

### Problem 3: "Network Error" or "Connection Failed"
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Check your internet connection
- âœ… Verify firewall/antivirus isn't blocking Cursor
- âœ… Try disabling VPN if you're using one
- âœ… Check if OpenAI API is accessible: https://status.openai.com/

### Problem 4: API Key Works in Browser but Not in Cursor
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Restart Cursor completely (close all windows)
- âœ… Clear Cursor cache:
   - Close Cursor
   - Delete: `%APPDATA%\Cursor\Cache`
   - Restart Cursor
- âœ… Check if you have multiple Cursor installations conflicting

### Problem 5: Settings Not Saving
**Solutions:**
- âœ… Make sure Cursor has write permissions to settings file
- âœ… Check if settings.json is read-only
- âœ… Try running Cursor as Administrator (temporarily)
- âœ… Check disk space availability

## Verification Steps

1. **Test the API Key:**
   - Open Cursor Chat (usually `Ctrl + L` or `Cmd + L`)
   - Ask a simple question like "Hello, can you hear me?"
   - If it responds, your API key is working!

2. **Check API Usage:**
   - Visit: https://platform.openai.com/usage
   - You should see API calls being made when using Cursor

3. **Check Cursor Logs:**
   - Open Command Palette (`Ctrl + Shift + P`)
   - Type: `Developer: Toggle Developer Tools`
   - Check Console for any API-related errors

## Your Current Settings Location

Your Cursor settings are located at:
```
C:\Users\pc\AppData\Roaming\Cursor\User\settings.json
```

## Quick Fix Checklist

- [ ] API key copied correctly (starts with `sk-`)
- [ ] No extra spaces in the API key
- [ ] OpenAI account has credits/active billing
- [ ] Cursor restarted after adding key
- [ ] Internet connection is working
- [ ] Firewall/antivirus not blocking Cursor
- [ ] Using latest version of Cursor

## Still Not Working?

If none of the above works:

1. **Check Cursor Version:**
   - Help â†’ About Cursor
   - Update to the latest version if needed

2. **Try Alternative Model Provider:**
   - Some Cursor versions support other providers
   - Check Cursor settings for "Model Provider" options

3. **Contact Support:**
   - Cursor Support: https://cursor.sh/support
   - Include error messages and your Cursor version

4. **Check for Updates:**
   - Cursor may have changed how API keys are configured
   - Update to the latest version

## Security Note

âš ï¸ **IMPORTANT:** Never share your API key publicly or commit it to version control!
- API keys are stored securely by Cursor
- Don't paste your key in chat or public forums
- If you accidentally exposed your key, regenerate it at: https://platform.openai.com/api-keys


","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"QUICK_START_GITHUB.md","contents":"# Quick Start: Connect to GitHub

Since you already have GitHub, here's the fastest way to set everything up:

## ðŸš€ Quick Setup (3 Steps)

### Step 1: Install SpecStory Extension in Cursor
1. Open Cursor
2. Press `Ctrl+Shift+P`
3. Type: `Extensions: Install Extension`
4. Search for: **SpecStory**
5. Click Install

**This automatically saves ALL your conversations!** No manual copying needed.

### Step 2: Create GitHub Repository
1. Go to: https://github.com/new
2. Repository name: `cursor-conversations` (or any name you like)
3. Choose: **Private** (recommended for conversations)
4. **Don't** check "Initialize with README"
5. Click "Create repository"

### Step 3: Connect to GitHub
Run this script:
```powershell
.\connect-to-github.bat
```

When prompted, paste your GitHub repository URL (from step 2).

**That's it!** ðŸŽ‰

---

## How It Works Now

1. **You chat in Cursor** â†’ SpecStory automatically saves to `.specstory/` folder
2. **Run backup script** â†’ `auto-backup-cursor.bat` commits and pushes to GitHub
3. **Everything is backed up online!** âœ…

---

## Daily Usage

After chatting in Cursor, just run:
```powershell
.\auto-backup-cursor.bat
```

This will:
- âœ… Commit all new conversations
- âœ… Push to GitHub automatically
- âœ… Keep everything backed up online

---

## Optional: Automatic Backup Every Hour

To automatically backup every hour without running the script:

```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File setup-scheduled-backup.ps1
```

---

## Your GitHub Repository

After setup, you can view all your conversations at:
`https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/YOUR_REPO_NAME`

All conversations are saved as markdown files, easy to read and search!

---

## Need Help?

- **Can't push?** GitHub might ask you to authenticate - just follow the prompts
- **SpecStory not working?** Make sure extension is installed and enabled
- **Want to backup manually?** Just run `auto-backup-cursor.bat` anytime

---

**You're all set!** Your conversations are now automatically saved and backed up to GitHub! ðŸš€

","fileGitContext":{}},{"relativeWorkspacePath":"README_DATA_STRUCTURE.md","contents":"# FQC Data Storage Structure - Example Files

## ðŸ“ Files Created

1. **example_sqlite_data.sql** - Complete SQLite database schema with example data
2. **example_google_sheets_structure.csv** - Google Sheets layout with example data
3. **This README** - Explanation of the data structure

---

## ðŸ“Š Example Scenario

**Device:** SLC251EG000123 (Ember Gray)  
**Operator:** John Doe  
**Journey:**

```
08:30 â†’ Device Created
09:00 â†’ Frequency Test #1 â†’ âŒ FAILED (Right to left shift, Wire sound)
09:20 â†’ Rework: Driver INTERCHANGE (45 min)
10:30 â†’ Frequency Test #2 â†’ âœ… PASSED
11:00 â†’ Song Test #1 â†’ âŒ FAILED (Bass distortion)
11:25 â†’ Rework: HEADBAND CHANGE (90 min)
14:00 â†’ Complete QC + FQC â†’ âœ… PASSED
16:45 â†’ Device Shipped
```

---

## ðŸ—„ï¸ SQLite Database Structure (9 Tables)

### 1. **devices** - Master device list
- Serial Number (PK)
- MAC ID
- Color, Status, Iterations
- Final Result

### 2. **operators** - Worker information
- Operator ID (PK)
- Name, Devices handled
- Work hours, Efficiency

### 3. **sessions** - Every work session
- Session ID (PK)
- Links: Serial Number, Operator
- Type, Duration, Status changes

### 4. **frequency_tests** - All frequency tests
- Test ID (PK)
- Parameters: Start/End Hz, Duration
- Balance, Loop settings
- Result, Issues, Solutions
- **Iteration Number** (tracks attempts)

### 5. **song_tests** - All song tests
- Test ID (PK)
- Songs played, Volume, Balance
- Result, Issues, Remarks
- **Iteration Number**

### 6. **fqc_records** - Final Quality Checks
- FQC ID (PK)
- 11 checklist items (PASS/FAIL)
- Images (base64), Descriptions
- Auto-pulled previous test results
- **Iteration Number**

### 7. **rework_history** - All repairs/fixes
- Rework ID (PK)
- Reason, Failed test type
- Actions taken, Time to repair
- **Iteration Number**

### 8. **performance_metrics** - Daily stats
- Calculated per operator/day
- Avg times, Yield %, Efficiency

### 9. **sync_queue** - Tracks cloud sync
- Pending uploads to Google Sheets
- Synced status

---

## ðŸ“ˆ Google Sheets Structure (10 Sheets)

### Sheet 1: Devices
Master list of all devices

### Sheet 2: Operators  
All workers and their stats

### Sheet 3: Sessions
Every work session logged

### Sheet 4: FrequencyTests
All frequency tests with full details

### Sheet 5: SongTests
All song tests with results

### Sheet 6: FQCRecords
Final quality checks with images

### Sheet 7: ReworkHistory
All repairs and fixes applied

### Sheet 8: PerformanceMetrics
Daily/weekly operator performance

### Sheet 9: EmailRecipients
Email addresses for daily reports

### Sheet 10: Images
Separate sheet for base64 image storage (keeps main sheets clean)

---

## ðŸ”„ Data Flow Example

### Iteration Tracking
```
Device SLC251EG000123:

frequency_tests table:
â”œâ”€â”€ iteration_number = 1 â†’ FAIL (Right to left shift)
â””â”€â”€ iteration_number = 2 â†’ PASS (after INTERCHANGE)

song_tests table:
â”œâ”€â”€ iteration_number = 1 â†’ FAIL (Bass distortion)
â””â”€â”€ iteration_number = 2 â†’ PASS (after HEADBAND CHANGE)

rework_history table:
â”œâ”€â”€ rework_iteration = 1 â†’ INTERCHANGE (45 min)
â””â”€â”€ rework_iteration = 2 â†’ HEADBAND CHANGE (90 min)

fqc_records table:
â””â”€â”€ iteration_number = 1 â†’ PASS (final check)
```

### Status Progression
```
sessions table tracks status changes:
Session 1: ASSEMBLY_COMPLETE â†’ FREQ_TEST_FAILED
Session 2: FREQ_TEST_FAILED â†’ FREQ_TEST_PASSED
Session 3: FREQ_TEST_PASSED â†’ SONG_TEST_FAILED
Session 4: SONG_TEST_FAILED â†’ FQC_PASSED
```

---

## ðŸ“Š Key Features

### 1. **Multiple Iterations Support**
- Each test has `iteration_number`
- Easy to track 1st attempt vs 2nd vs 3rd
- Query: `WHERE iteration_number = 1` â†’ First attempts only

### 2. **Complete Audit Trail**
- Every action timestamped
- Operator attribution
- Before/After status tracking

### 3. **Efficient Retrieval**
```sql
-- Get device full history
SELECT * FROM sessions WHERE serial_number = 'SLC251EG000123' ORDER BY start_time;

-- Get only failed tests
SELECT * FROM frequency_tests WHERE result = 'FAIL';

-- Get all reworks
SELECT * FROM rework_history WHERE serial_number = 'SLC251EG000123';
```

### 4. **Google Sheets Sync**
- Local SQLite â†’ Fast operations
- Batch sync every 5 min â†’ Google Sheets
- sync_queue tracks what's pending

### 5. **Image Handling**
- Compressed to 60% quality
- Base64 encoded
- Stored in separate "Images" sheet
- Linked by Image ID

---

## ðŸ“§ Daily Email Summary

Generated from this data:

```
Subject: Daily QC Report - 2025-10-13

ðŸ“Š Production Summary
âœ… 15 devices processed
âœ… 13 passed (86.7%)

toolFormerData.rawArgs: {"search_term": "Cursor IDE where are chat conversations stored Windows AppData"}
toolFormerData.name: web_search
toolFormerData.params: {"searchTerm":"Cursor IDE where are chat conversations stored Windows AppData"}
toolFormerData.result:
{"references":[{"title":"Web Search Results","chunk":"I'm sorry to hear that you've lost your chat history in Cursor. Here are some steps you can take to attempt recovery:

1. **Check Cursor's History Panel**: Cursor stores chat history locally in a SQLite database on your machine. You can access past conversations from the history panel:
   - Click the history icon in the Agent sidepane.
   - Press `Alt+Ctrl+'` to open the history panel.
   - From there, you can manage chats by editing titles, deleting, or opening full conversations. ([docs.cursor.com](https://docs.cursor.com/agent/chat/history?utm_source=openai))

2. **Use Cursor's Checkpoints Feature**: Cursor automatically creates checkpoints, which are snapshots of the Agent's changes to your codebase. These allow you to undo modifications if needed:
   - From the input box, click the `Restore Checkpoint` button on previous requests.
   - From a message, click the `+` button when hovering over it.
   - Note that checkpoints track only Agent changes and are stored locally, separate from Git. ([docs.cursor.com](https://docs.cursor.com/en/agent/chat/checkpoints?utm_source=openai))

3. **Utilize Third-Party Recovery Tools**: There are tools developed by the community to help recover lost Cursor data:
   - **CursorRecovery**: A Python utility that extracts file history from Cursor's local storage. It helps retrieve and organize previous versions of your code files. You can find it here: ([github.com](https://github.com/bbostock/CursorRecovery?utm_source=openai))
   - **Cursor View**: A local tool to view, search, and export all your Cursor AI chat histories. It scans your local Cursor application data directories and extracts chat data from the SQLite databases. More information is available at: ([github.com](https://github.com/saharmor/cursor-view?utm_source=openai))

4. **Check for Corrupted Chat History**: If Cursor becomes unresponsive or chats fail to load, it might be due to corrupted chat history data. In such cases, you can try removing the problematic workspace storage:
   - Navigate to the workspace storage directory on your system.
   - Identify and remove the corrupted workspace directory.
   - This solution preserves other workspace data while removing only the problematic workspace. ([github.com](https://github.com/cursor/cursor/issues/3307?utm_source=openai))

5. **Contact Cursor Support**: If the above steps don't resolve the issue, consider reaching out to Cursor's support team or community forums for assistance. They may have additional insights or solutions specific to your situation.

To prevent future data loss, it's advisable to regularly back up your chat history. Tools like **SpecStory** can automatically save and export your Cursor chat history, ensuring you have backups readily available. ([cursordocs.com](https://cursordocs.com/en/tutorial/02-cursor-chat-history-export?utm_source=openai))

I hope these steps help you recover your lost chat history. "}],"isFinal":true}
